presentation.title: Leveraging the Web Platform for the Web of Things

slide.title: Abstract
slide.p: Web Architecture provides a general-purpose way of establishing an interlinked network of resources, which are interacted with through the exchange of representations of their state. We argue that the Web of Things fits well into this general framework, and thus should be built firmly on the foundation provided by Web Architecture. We also argue that in order to allow an evolutionary path towards a Web of Things, it is important to take small and incremental steps towards the final goal, instead of trying to establish a grand Web of Things Architecture in one monolithic step. One interesting first step could be to focus on Activity Streams as one way how streams of resource updates can be represented in a uniform, extensible, and machine-readable way.

ul.li: The last mile (how to connect the thing) might be better left to specialists
What matters is identification and interaction, but only with a representation
Instead, focus on scenarios such as aggregation, filtering, republication, subscription, ...
How to interact with representations to achieve application goals

slide.title: Sitting on the wrong branch can kill you

ul.li: Atom's model was right but the foundation was too short-lived
Once, there was a flourishing loosely coupled Atom Landscape
Disliking XML became trendy and that sealed Atom's fate
Atom's future didn't happen, but it still needs to
WoT scenarios are like newsfeeds on steroids (scale, volume, variety)
Follow the footsteps of previous H2M and M2M success stories of the Web
only provide interaction models, do not provide any domain data models
Provide building blocks so that people can easily design their own media types
Keep everything loosely coupled, so that spec work can adjust to reality
A Web of Things is still a Web, and not something else entirely
Remember WAP's complete parallel universe? Because: Mobile is different!
